raw_text:
Bank set to leave rates on hold
 
 UK interest rates are set to remain on hold at 4.75% following the latest meeting of the Bank of England.
 
 The Bank's rate-setting committee has put up rates five times in the past year but rates have been on hold since September amid signs of a slowdown. Economic growth slowed in the previous quarter, as manufacturing output fell, while consumer confidence has slipped. There is also growing evidence that the previously booming UK housing market is now cooling.
 
 House prices fell 0.4% in October, according to the Nationwide, their biggest monthly fall since February 2001. Last month, Bank of England governor Mervyn King said that the economy had hit a "softer patch" after rapid economic growth in the first half of 2004. Richard Jeffrey, chief economist at Bridgewell Securities, said it was very unlikely that the Bank of England would put rates up again this time around. "There have been sufficient signs in the economy of a slowdown to stay the Bank of England's hand," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. However, Mr Jeffrey said he believed the slowdown in economic activity was temporary and it was dangerous to assume that rates had peaked. "I still think interest rates are going up," he said. "We are not out of the woods."
llama3.2:1b: The Bank of England is set to leave interest rates on hold at 4.75%.
The rate-setting committee has held rates five times in a year, and has put them on hold since September due to signs of slowing economic growth and cooling housing markets.
Despite this, some economists believe the slowdown may be temporary and interest rates may still rise.
llama3.2:3b: UK interest rates will remain at 4.75%, following five rate increases in the past year amid signs of a slowdown.
Economic growth slowed, with manufacturing output falling and consumer confidence slipping, as the UK housing market cools down.
The Bank of England is unlikely to increase rates again this time around, but its chief economist believes interest rates may rise soon despite a temporary slowdown.
gemma2:2b: The Bank of England has decided to keep interest rates at 4.75%.
The decision follows a slowdown in economic growth, including falling manufacturing output and consumer confidence, as well as signs of cooling in the housing market.
Despite this temporary slowdown, some economists believe interest rate increases are likely in the future.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK interest rates will remain at 4.75% for the next quarter, according to Bank of England's rate-setting committee.
Economic growth has slowed in the previous quarter, with manufacturing output falling and consumer confidence slipping.
The economy is seeing signs of a slowdown, as house prices fell 0.4% in October.
Mr Jeffrey, chief economist at Bridgewell Securities, believes that economic activity will remain weak, but says it's not likely to peak soon.
He suggests that rates may need to rise temporarily, although he remains uncertain about the future direction of the economy.
qwen2.5:1.5b: UK Bank of England interest rates set to remain unchanged at 4.75%, with policymakers indicating potential upcoming rate hikes due to signs of economic slowdown and cooling housing market, though recent data suggests a temporary slowdown is likely to be short-lived.
qwen2.5:3b: UK interest rates are set to remain at 4.75% following the Bank of England's meeting, despite rate hikes five times in the past year.
The slowdown is attributed to economic growth slowing and a decline in consumer confidence, with signs pointing towards a cooling UK housing market.
House prices fell by 0.4% in October, their largest monthly drop since February 2001.
Bank of England Governor Mervyn King noted that the economy has hit a "softer patch" after rapid growth.
Economist Richard Jeffrey does not expect further rate hikes, citing economic slowdown signs but still believes rates may rise again as economic activity is expected to remain unstable.
opencoder:1.5b: The bank is expected to leave hold on interest rates as per latest meeting of the Bank of England.
The rate-setting committee has put up rates five times in past year but have been on hold since September due to signs of slowdown in economic growth.
The market for housing has started to cool, and prices have fallen 0.4% according to Nationwide reports.
However, as per previous statements, King Mervyn said the economy had slowed after rapid growth during first half of 2004.
The reports also highlight a possible recovery plan by Richard Jeffrey, which he believed might allow the Bank to settle interest rates again.

However, Mr Jeffrey confirmed his belief that the slowdown was temporary and dangerous - implying that likely, the rate hike is due to increased demand for bonds or other structured products which could impact the overall economy.
smollm:1.7b: The Bank set to leave rates on hold at 4.75% following the latest meeting of the Bank of England.
UK interest rates are set to remain on hold at 4.75% following the latest meeting of the Bank of England.
The Bank's rate-setting committee has put up rates five times in the past year but rates have been on hold since September amid signs of a slowdown.
Economic growth slowed in the previous quarter, as manufacturing output fell, while consumer confidence has slipped.
There is also growing evidence that the previously booming UK housing market is now cooling.
House prices fell 0.4% in October, according to the Nationwide, their biggest monthly fall since February 2001.
Last month, Bank of England governor Mervyn King said that the economy had hit a "softer patch" after rapid economic growth in the first half of 2004.
Richard Jeffrey, chief economist at Bridgewell Securities, said it was very unlikely that the Bank of England would put rates up again this time around.
"There have been sufficient signs in the economy of a slowdown to stay the Bank of England's hand," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.
However, Mr Jeffrey said he believed the slowdown in economic activity was temporary and it was dangerous to assume that rates had peaked.
"I still think interest rates are going up," he said.
"We are not out of the woods."
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The Bank of England set UK interest rates on hold at 4.75%.
The rate-setting committee has been on the rates five times in the past year, but they have remained on hold since September after signs of economic slowdown and cooling consumer confidence.
House prices fell by 0.4% in October, their biggest drop since February 2001.
Richard Jeffrey suggested the Bank is likely to hold rates unless there are sufficient signs of slowdowns.
tinyllama:1.1b: UK interest rates remain on hold at 4.75% following the latest meeting of the Bank of England, as the recent rate increases have yet to provide a sustainable boost to economic growth.
House prices fell in October, according to Nationwide, adding to signs that the previously booming UK housing market has cooled.
The Bank's rate-setting committee put rates up five times last year but has not yet increased them again, with economists predicting a softening of the economy over the coming months.
While house prices have fallen, there remains strong evidence that the once-fierce property market has begun to cool, according to Bridgewell Securities' chief economist.
tinydolphin:1.1b: UK interest rates remain on hold at 4.75% after the latest meeting of the Bank of England's rate-setting committee, which found that economic growth has slowed amid signs of a slowdown in manufacturing output and consumer confidence.
Economic growth has also fallen since September.
House prices dropped 0.4% in October according to Nationwide, their biggest monthly fall since February 2001.

Some economists predict that the Bank of England will raise rates again in November, with Mervyn King stating that the economy had reached a "softer patch" after rapid economic growth in the first half of 2004.

Richard Jeffrey, chief economist at Bridgewell Securities, expressed his pessimism about the Bank of England's ability to maintain low interest rates, saying it was very unlikely that the bank would put rates up again this time around.
However, he argued that the slowdown in economic activity is temporary and there is a danger of overshooting by keeping rates too low for too long, calling for more stimulus.

Despite the uncertainty surrounding the Bank of England's future policy decisions, interest rates remain on hold at 4.75%, serving as a benchmark for many other banks and financial institutions around the world.
phi:2.7b: Interest rates in the UK will remain at 4.75% after the Bank of England's latest meeting, following five rate hikes in the last 12 months but no increase due to signs of a slowdown including a fall in economic growth and consumer confidence as well as evidence that the housing market is cooling down.
While it's unlikely for rates to go up again this time around, experts say there is still risk and caution that they may not have peaked.
orca-mini:3b: The Bank of England is likely to keep interest rates steady at 4.75% following the latest meeting, as signs of a slowdown in economic growth and a cooling housing market continue.
hermes3:3b: UK bank holding interest rates at 4.75% after 5 increases this year; likely to stay hold due to slowing economic growth, manufacturing output fall, and cooling housing market.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Bank of England has decided to keep interest rates on hold at 4.75% after the latest meeting, due to signs of a slowdown in the economy.
This marks the fifth time rates have been set this year.
House prices fell 0.4% in October, marking their biggest monthly decline since February 2001.
While some believe the economic slowdown is temporary, many fear it may be permanent, leading them to believe that interest rates could rise again in the future.
chatgpt-4o-latest: UK interest rates are expected to remain at 4.75% following the Bank of England's latest meeting.

After five rate hikes in the past year, rates have been on hold since September due to signs of economic slowdown, including declining manufacturing output, weaker consumer confidence, and a cooling housing market.
House prices fell 0.4% in October, the largest drop since 2001.
Bank of England governor Mervyn King acknowledged a "softer patch" in the economy after strong growth earlier in 2004.
Economist Richard Jeffrey stated that the slowdown has likely deterred further rate increases for now but warned that rates may still rise in the future.
stablelm2:1.6b: The Bank of England will maintain a hold on UK interest rates at 4%, despite five rate hikes in the past year.
The decision was made by the Bank's rate-setting committee, as economic growth slowed and signs of a slowdown emerged.
House prices also fell 0.4% in October according to the Nationwide, marking their largest monthly drop since February.
While it is unlikely the Bank will increase rates again, some experts believe it could still rise in the near future.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Bank of England has decided to maintain its benchmark interest rate at 4.75%, following a fifth increase in the past year, which began in September due to signs of economic slowdown.
Key indicators showing this slowdown include decreased manufacturing output and a dip in consumer confidence, as well as the UK housing market's cooling trend.
In October, house prices fell 0.4%, marking their largest monthly decline since February 2001.

Although Bank of England Governor Mervyn King previously stated the economy had entered a "softer patch," chief economist Richard Jeffrey from Bridgewell Securities predicts it's unlikely rates will be raised further, citing numerous slowdown signals.
Despite this, Jeffrey cautions that the downturn may be temporary and emphasizes the need to avoid prematurely concluding that interest rates have peaked.
